definition: to build up public opinion/to create a fuss
to make/to build/to manufacture/to invent/to fabricate/to go to/party (in a lawsuit or legal agreement)/crop/classifier for crops
carriage/sedan chair/world
abbr. for 論語|论语[Lun2 yu3], The Analects (of Confucius)
opinion/view/theory/doctrine/to discuss/to talk about/to regard/to consider/per/by the (kilometer, hour etc)

sentences.english: but at the same time it was really just a buildup in my mind.
sentences.chinese: 但是同时我觉得这只是制造舆论。

sentences.english: The gig was given a big buildup on both press and TV.
sentences.chinese: 爵士演唱会被报刊和电视大造舆论。

sentences.english: Uruguayan football has never failed to generate opinion over the years.
sentences.chinese: 乌拉圭足球这些年来并没有少制造舆论。

sentences.english: It was just a buildup of consumer expectations, you know, people were expecting more
sentences.chinese: 就是给消费者预期制造舆论，人们期望更多。

definition: to agitate for/to enthusiastically promote
to start rumours and create trouble
to use the current topic to put over one's own ideas/to use sth as a pretext to make a fuss
lit. to wave a banner as if it were a tiger skin (idiom)/fig. to borrow sb's prestige/to take the name of a great cause as a shield
pinyin: la1 da4 qi2 zuo4 hu3 pi2

definition: lit. to have sufficient reason to send troops (idiom)/to do something with good reason/to have just cause
to vilify sb wantonly/unrestrained attack (on sb)
to discredit/to defame/to smear sb's name/to bring shame upon (oneself or one's family etc)/to blacken (e.g. commando's face for camouflage)/to black out or obliterate (e.g. censored words)
to sing sb's praises (mostly derogatory)
to confuse right and wrong (idiom)
to reverse a verdict/to present different views on a historical person or verdict
lit. Sima Zhao's intentions are obvious to everyone (idiom)/fig. an open secret
pinyin: Si1 ma3 Zhao1 zhi1 xin1 lu4 ren2 jie1 zhi1

definition: to push the wave and add to the billows (idiom); to add momentum/to encourage sth to get bigger/to add fuel to the fire
lit. to invert black and white (idiom); to distort the truth deliberately/to misrepresent the facts/to invert right and wrong
to obscure the facts (idiom); to mislead the public with prevarication and deliberate falsehoods
(of a piece of writing) long and tedious (idiom)/verbose
lit. chasing the wind and clutching at shadows (idiom); fig. groundless accusations/to act on hearsay evidence
